message.content:
cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.DS, cs.SI, cs.IT. 

The paper deals with a bandit problem, which is a classic topic in machine learning and optimization. The use of a graph structure to model the comparisons between nodes suggests that the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.LG (Machine Learning). The focus on sample complexity and PAC (probably approximately correct) learning also suggests that the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence). The use of stochastic information and the need to estimate differences between nodes suggests that the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms). The analysis of the impact of graph topology on sample complexity suggests that the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.SI (Social and Information Networks). Finally, the use of information theory concepts such as mutual information suggests that the paper may belong to the sub-category of cs.IT (Information Theory).
